question: Does CX3CR1 expression on Th2 cells promote airway inflammation in allergen-induced murine models of asthma? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Transfer of WT CD4(+) T cells into CX3CR1-deficient mice restored the cardinal features of asthma, and CX3CR1-blocking reagents prevented airway inflammation in CX3CR1-deficient recipients injected with WT T(H)2 cells.
content.source_2: Despite allergen sensitization and challenge, neither genetic deletion of CX3CR1 nor administration of CX3CR1-blocking reagents altered airway hyperresponsiveness or eosinophilic infiltration, suggesting Th2-driven lung pathology proceeds independently of CX3CR1.
content.source_3: CX3CR1-dependent survival was not detected for T(H)2 cells during airway inflammation; any survival advantage attributable to CX3CR1 was limited to homeostatic settings and peripheral inflammatory sites.
